posts.title: About
posts.markdown:
![alt](/content/images/2018/03/Annie-Sanderson-Main-Blog-Picture.jpeg)

Hello....

My name is Annie, and I welcome you warmly to my personal blog and home for my thoughts, feelings, ideas and all the things that inspire me as an individual.

Over recent months, I have come to learn and appreciate that life is such a precious, and wondrous gift that should be held sacred and enjoyed by doing the things YOU love and feel most passionate about. 

I am actively pursuing this personal goal of mine through my love for art, crafts and photography, of which, I'll be sharing on here in the next coming months.

Blogging is a new found love for me so, I hope its content will provide you inspiration to start thinking about living your life to the absolute fullest and to follow all those hidden dreams like I have begun to.

Let's start this journey together by doing what we love.

*Much love,*

*Annie x*

posts.title: ‎”If tears could build a stairway, and memories a lane, I’d walk right up to Heaven, and bring you home again”.
posts.markdown:
This post is a open letter to my grandmother who died suddenly on 10/10/2011; my 31st birthday. What should have been a joyful occasion marked a tragic event which will be remembered for years to come.

Dear Grandmother,
You are a strong, courageous and intelligent woman. You cared for and loved your children deeply; even though sometimes this was not always communicated verbally, your love was unconditional and demonstrated by the actions you took.

It is still hard to believe you are gone. Our time together was a short one. Knowing I will not hear the familiar voice on the end of the telephone or see your smile during a visit is hard to bear but I know it is something I will eventually come to terms with over time.

My only comfort is that I know in my heart your legacy will continue on through the lives of your children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. You will never be forgotten but remembered in our hearts and minds until the end of time. I pray you will rest in peace and continue to watch over your loved ones, protecting them, until we all meet again one day in heaven.

Lovingly yours,
Annie

posts.title: 3 Reasons Why I Love Hastings (And You Should, Too!)
posts.markdown:
Hastings. The seaside town situated along the south coast is the place I call home and here are top five reasons why. 

**1|** Hastings is hugely popular for its largest onshore fishing fleet supplying Hastings with an vibrant industry and main tourist attraction. If you are early bird like me, pop down to Hastings Stade and take a walk amongst the fishing boats to catch a glimpse of the fishermen bringing in their catch of the day. The fish is collected and transported to the Fish Market, also situated along the Stade, ready for selling to the general public. You will certainly be guaranteed of the finest, fresh and local fish Hastings has to offer and not be disappointed.

![alt](/content/images/2016/09/DSCN0679.JPG)

![alt](http://)

![alt](/content/images/2016/09/DSCN0680-1.JPG)

**2|**The Old Town is a vibrant oasis with its well preserved medieval to Victorian architecture and authentic community feel. Many key events take place in the Old Town such as Hastings Old Town Week, Jack in the Green and Bonfire Possession which draw in huge crowds however, the main attraction for me (and my all-time favourite pastime) is perusing through the small boutique shops! Here you will find independent, local shops displaying all kinds of unique treasures to buy and take home. Something which you would not be able to find in any of the big cities. 

Pictures of the Old Town plus shops

**3|** Hastings Pier

![alt](http://)

![alt](http://)

![alt](http://)

**5|** Alexandra Park well known for its diverse and abundant wildlife, especially at the Northern end, known as 'Old Roar Gill' which is now a Local Nature Reserve. Gorgeous shades of green displayed from Bucks-hole Reservoir to Harmers Pond paints the perfect meeting place for family and friends to have a picnic, gentle walk or a spot of football. I enjoy spending time in the park especially in the warm summer evenings where I can unwind and relax after a stressful day at work.

Pictures of Alexandra Park

![alt](http://)

![alt](http://)

![alt](http://)

Pictures of Alexandra Park

posts.title: Race for Life 14.06.2015
posts.markdown:
![alt](/content/images/2015/07/Race-for-Life-14062015-13.jpg)

Today, I completed my first 5K sponsored charity event for Cancer Research UK's Race for Life and even though I'm thoroughly exhausted; I enjoyed every minute of it. 

Race for Life is the largest women-only fundraising event where women of all ages come together for a united cause to raise money for cancer research. 

The experience was an emotional one as I have lost close friends and family to this awful disease but it is very rewarding to know I'm making a difference by raising money and awareness for such an important and vital charity. It was touching to see so many women sharing a common bond in their fight towards cancer which has affected so many lives.

I wasn't alone in the race and participated alongside my work colleague and friend Georgie Luxford. Georgie is such an strong woman, she kept me motivated throughout and was such a inspiration. I couldn't have done it without her and there were times I wanted her to go ahead of me as I felt I was slowing her down but she stayed with me until we crossed the finishing line. Similarly, I am grateful to all those that sponsored us, sent messages of good luck and for cheering us on the day. It was very much appreciated and meant so much. It was something I never thought I would do or could ever do but I am very glad I did.

Here's to next year! 10k perhaps? Maybe, who knows...

posts.title: How to make Christmas Snowflake Gift Tags
posts.markdown:
I am feeling inspired on this warm September Sunday morning to make something wonderful with my new purchases from Hobbycraft. My mood is Christmassy, and yes, I realise to some, Christmas might seem like a long way off but if you've got a lot of friends and family to make for, now is the perfect time to start! 

These beautiful Christmas Snowflake gift tags are of my own design and perfect as a simple project for first-time crafters to get to grips with. 

***Suitable for:*** Beginners 

***Time allowed:*** 10 - 15 minutes

***You will need***

**1|** Selection of Assorted Festive Washi Tape (I have used Hobbycraft Assorted Christmas Washi Tape 3 Pack £3.00)

**2|** Twine (I have used Hobbycraft Green Twine £2.00)

**3|** Tags (I have used Kraft Luggage Tags 30 Pack £1.50 5 cm in length) 

**4|** Self Adhesive Gems (I have used 3 mm green gems)

**5|** Scissors

**6|** Craft Tweezers

**7|** Punch (I have used Hobbycraft Snowflake Small Punch £2.00)

**8|** Green bow to decorate

***How to make***

**1|** Place tag through the groove of the punch (use the snowflake as a guide) and position where you want the snowflake to be on your tag. Once you are happy with the position, clasp together to make a snowflake punch.

**2|** Measure 11.5 mm of washi tape, cut and put aside. Place the strip of the washi tape about roughly 1 mm above the snowflake (as shown below) but not so, that it is touching the punch out of the snowflake.
Wrap the washi tape around both sides of the tag and cut to measure.

**3|** Carefully decorate the points of the snowflake with self adhesive gems using craft tweezers.

**4|** Cut roughly 12 mm of the twine and thread the twine through the hole of the tag to make a loop. Affix a small green bow to the washi tape to decorate. 
Now you are ready to use your Christmas tags. I will be stamping mine with names of family and friends but they will look equally wonderful with handwritten names.

![alt](/content/images/2017/05/Christmas-Snowflake-Gift-Tag.jpg)

***Happy Crafting!***

<style>
  H6 {
    color: red;
  }
</style>

How to make

I will be stamping mine with names of family and friends but they will look equally wonderful with handwritten names.

posts.title: Top Ten Craft Essentials
posts.markdown:
<style>
h6 {
  color: red;
}
</style>
If you are a creative individual like me; you will find that inspiration can strike at anytime; from the very early hours of the morning to late at night so, it is vital to have your craft box stocked and ready with essential crafting supplies.

Here are my **top ten** craft essentials to get you started.

###### **1** | **Card**



![alt](/content/images/2015/09/Paper.jpg)
**PHOTOCREDIT:** Hobbycraft

###### **2** | **Glues**

Keep your creations intact and secure with these products; a glue gun, sticky pads, glue dots, double-sided tape and specialist craft glue; tape pen are all basic essentials and available from all Arts and Crafts superstores such as Hobbycraft or The Range.

![alt](/content/images/2015/09/Specialist-Glue.jpg)
**PHOTOCREDIT:** Hobbycraft

###### **3** | **Cutting and Trimming**

Ensure you have the basic tools for cutting and trimming such as a cutting mat, trimmer, craft knife, craft mat and pair of scissors. All available from Arts and Crafts superstores such as Hobbycraft or The Range.

![alt](/content/images/2015/09/Cutting-Mats.jpg)
**PHOTOCREDIT:** Hobbycraft

###### **4** | **Ink**

With so many inks to choose from you will be spoilt for choice; crimson red, emerald green or hot pink are some of the inks available to stamp greetings for special occasions or create intricate design images to use on your craft projects. All available from Arts and Crafts superstores such as Hobbycraft or The Range.

![alt](/content/images/2015/09/ink-pads-cat-square.jpg)
**PHOTOCREDIT:** Hobbycraft

###### **5** | **Die-Cutting Machine**

No crafter would be without the Sizzix Big Shot Plus. For the current price of £128.00, you can purchase a Sizzix Big Shot Plus Starter Kit complete with die shapes, embossing folders and paper samples. Versatility at its best bringing together die-cutting or embossing techniques using a variety of different materials.

![alt](/content/images/2015/09/Sizzix-Big-Shot-.jpg)
**PHOTOCREDIT:** Hobbycraft

###### **6** | **Punches**

Punch your way through paperstock to create perfect shapes. All available from Arts and Crafts superstores such as Hobbycraft or The Range.

![alt](/content/images/2015/09/craft-punches-cat-square.jpg)
**PHOTOCREDIT:** Hobbycraft

###### **7** | **Patterned Papers**

I love patterned paper to cover my cards and I thoroughly recommend products from Papermania Capsule Collection like Parkstone Pink shown in the image below.

![alt](/content/images/2015/11/Patterned-Paper-1.jpg)
**PHOTOCREDIT:** Hobbycraft

###### **8** | **Embellishments**

Embellish your designs with layers of beautiful gems, fabric flower toppers or shiny buttons.

![alt](/content/images/2015/09/buttons-brads-and-flatbacks-cat-square.jpg)
**PHOTOCREDIT:** Hobbycraft

###### **9** | **Ribbons**

Pretty patterned ribbons and washi tape are the perfect way to decorate your craft projects and are available in adhesive, shimmer and glossy materials.

![alt](/content/images/2015/09/decorative-tape-cat-square.jpg)
**PHOTOCREDIT:** Hobbycraft

###### **10** | **Stamps**

Stamp! Stamp! Stamp! Add finishing touches to your cards with beautiful greetings and intricate design images, available in all shapes and sizes.

![alt](http://)
**PHOTOCREDIT:** Hobbycraft

posts.title: 14 Quotes to Inspire and Motivate You
posts.markdown:
Words can be incredibly soothing when in need of comfort or support. Words bring innovation, inspire creativity, increase motivation but more importantly remind ourselves how truly beautiful life can be. 

Here is a collection of my favourite 14 Inspirational and Motivational Quotes. I hope they will inspire you to do something wonderful today and give you the much needed kick-start for 2016!

posts.title: 10 Songs to Help Boost Your Workout
posts.markdown:
Do you find listening to your favorite songs can give you a boost of energy or motivation to power through to the end of a workout? For me, it is a excellent strategy for improving concentration and increased performance, which is why I am excited to share with you songs that keeps me motivated from beginning to end.

Here are my top ten songs, perfect to transform an intense, fat-burning workout into a fun sweat session that doesn't even feel like exercise!

Enjoy x 

######1. Calvin Harris, Dua Lipa | One Kiss 
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/DkeiKbqa02g" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>

######2. Sigala, Paloma Faith | Lullaby
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ghSQz2BcDQU" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>

######3. M-22 | First Time (ft. Medina)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/NPWgKzAMFB4" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>

######4. Jax Jones | Breathe (Official Video) ft. Ina Wroldsen
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/uGhKqb2Ow3E" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>

######5. TRU Concept & Nu Aspect | Said To You
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/mKmS3JiSN7Q" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>

######6. EDX | Touch Her, Feel Her (Original Mix)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/s5IbohgJplw" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>

######7. Calippo | Good for You (Original Club Mix)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/fXNV0kvbXtU" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>

######8. Sigma & Rita Ora | Coming Home
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/tS26xch5U24" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

######9. Gorgon City (ft. Katy Menditta) | Imagination
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/O48hUxxJxS8" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>

######10. Route 94 (ft Jess Glyne) | My Love
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/stKE-mSF1X4" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>

posts.title: It's All About the Dress

posts.title: Rome, Italy
posts.markdown:
It's been 8 months (I know, I am little behind on my blog posts!), since our short break to the beautiful cosmopolitan city of Rome, Italy. This is our 4th visit to date and no doubt, not the last. With so much to see and do, you are guaranteed each visit will always be different. I adore Rome. I love the vibrancy, the cultured but tremendously overcrowded streets filled with life, beauty and romance. I love the hospitality of the locals and their desire to make every moment you spend in their enchanted city even more special than the first. 

Rome, for me, is like a journey into the past, with thousands of years of art, architecture and culture on display for all to see. Exploring on foot the endless tangled lanes of cobbled streets and passing modern buildings are ruins such as Pantheon and Colosseum dating back thousands of years evoking the power of the former Roman Empire, in all its glory and stature.

Italy's eternal city is built on vast history and inspiration and although, this is not my first visit to Rome, I still feel a buzz of excitement when I see the magnificent Colosseum or St Peters Basilica illuminating the Italian skyline.

If you don't believe me, take some inspiration from some of the photographs I took to capture my holiday experience in Rome.

######1 |**Castel Sant'Angelo**

Castel Sant'Angelo is an hidden gem located in the Vatican City, with its towering cylindrical building and national museum. This fascinating fortress was built as a mausoleum for the Emperor Hadrian (AD130-139) but also a prison and used by former Popes who fled there for protection during times of danger. 

I was privileged enough to visit the Sant Angelo castle and National Museum of Castel Sant'Angelo which is like stepping into history, a home to various exhibits ranging from Renaissance paintings, sculptures antique military weapons as my photographs show.

![alt](/content/images/2017/09/InShot_20170910_064024864.jpg)

![alt](/content/images/2017/09/InShot_20170910_063946524.jpg)

![alt](/content/images/2017/09/InShot_20170910_064053454.jpg)

![alt](/content/images/2017/09/InShot_20170910_100014049.jpg)

######2 |**Colosseum**

The Colosseum or as known in Italian, "Collesso", also known as the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an oval amphitheatre situated in the heart of Rome, Italy. Built of concrete and sand, it is the largest amphitheatre ever built in the history. The Colosseum is located east of the Roman Forum. It boasts 80 arched entrances allowing easy access to 55,000 spectators, who were seated according to rank. 

Be prepared for lots of walking when visiting the Colosseum. It is a magnificent monument of enormous size, an ellipse 188m long and 156 wide. Comfortable shoes is a must!

![alt](/content/images/2017/09/InShot_20170910_064245230.jpg)

![alt](/content/images/2017/09/InShot_20170910_064122953.jpg)

######3 | **Trevi Fountain**

The Fontana di Trevi - or Trevi Fountain inspired by Roman arches, is the largest and most famous fountain in Rome, Italy. An impressive standing of 25.9 meters high and 19.8 meters wide. 

Trevi Fountain is situated in the busy Trevi square (Piazza di Trevi), within walking distance from the Spanish Steps and Piazza Navona. 
Tradition has it a coin thrown into the water guarantees a visitor's return to Rome and I can certainly vouch for that! This is my fourth visit!

![alt](/content/images/2017/09/InShot_20170910_104058207.jpg)

######4 |**St Peter's Square, Vatican City**
The striking square and its imposing colonnade lead to the greatest basilica of the Christian world: St Peter's Basilica (Basilica San Pietro). It also represents the core of the Vatican City, the smallest state in the world.  In the origins, the square used to be the place where Nerone Circus and Gardens where located, and where many Christians, including Saint Peter, suffered from martyrdom.

![alt](/content/images/2017/09/InShot_20170910_104409731.jpg)

######5 | **Fine Cuisine | Hotel Artemide** 

Romans love to eat. And they love to eat good food. Despite their easy-going "whatever happens, happens" attitude, they can become really picky when it comes to food. 

We had the pleasure of dining in the most exquisite restaurant situated right in our hotel. I urge you to experience the finest Italian cuisine at Ambrosia Restaurant of Hotel Artemide in Rome. The food served at Ambrosia Restaurant is locally sourced and freshly prepared on a daily basis for its guests. You'll never forget your experience at Ambrosia and it'll leave you wanting more! 

######Caprese Salad####
![alt](/content/images/2017/09/InShot_20170910_101138741.jpg)

######Tonnarelli (thick noodle pasta) with Shrimp
![alt](/content/images/2017/09/InShot_20170910_101021855-1.jpg)

Thank-you for taking the time to read my blog post on Rome - I hope it'll inspire you to visit this beautiful city and come to adore it as much as I do. 

Please feel free to comment on any of the content you see on this post using the details below.

Much Love
   x

<style>
h6 {
  color: skyblue;
}
</style>

The food served at Ambrosia Restaurant is locally sourced and freshly prepared on a daily basis for its guests. You'll never forget your experience at Ambrosia and it'll leave you wanting more!

Caprese Salad

Tonnarelli (thick noodle pasta) with Shrimp

Thank-you for taking the time to read my blog post on Rome - I hope it'll inspire you to visit this beautiful city and come to adore it as much as I do.

Please feel free to comment on any of the content you see on this post using the details below.

Much Love

posts.title: My Bucket List
posts.markdown:
**Last Updated:** 03/04/2017

I've always been fascinated with the idea of having a bucket list but I've never actually got round to writing a physical list until now.

I did have a go at compiling a few ideas for my Pinterest board last year, which was fun, as it encouraged me to try new things and have different experiences, but this year, I wanted to continue adding to the list but also capture the experiences visually and in physical form. 

So, I purchased a bucket list journal from my favourite independent small businesses high street website; *Not On The High Street*. Priced at just £23.00, which may seem a little expensive to some, it is definitely worth the extra pennies and a extremely good buy.

![alt](/content/images/2017/03/Bucket-List-Journal.jpg)

Not only is the journal beautifully bound in stylish black cloth, its packed with lots of inspiration! The journal includes a bucket list of 101 items and questions, motivational interviews with successful men and women, a space to insert pictures, inspirational quotes, beautiful photography from around the world, and a world map perfect to inspire anyone to start thinking about living their life to the absolute fullest and to follow all those hidden dreams.

So, without further ado, here's my list so far.....

######TRAVEL######

Travel to Venice, Italy | Go on Gondola Ride
Travel to Paris (again)
Travel solo

######BLOGGING######

~~Start a Blog~~	
Join a blog community
Post once per day for a whole month

######CAREER######

~~Achieve my Computing and Information Technology Practice Degree~~
~~Graduate from Open University~~
Achieve my PRINCE2 Foundation qualification

######LIFE######

Be a bridesmaid
Get a tattoo
Open a shop on Etsy
~~Create logo for my shop~~

######SKILLS######

Take a photography class
Take a cake making class
Learn how to play the guitar
Record a song 
Learn how to ride a bicycle
Learn how to play chess

######ADVENTURES/OUTDOORS######
Visit Go Ape
Ride the London Eye

######FITNESS/HEALTH######

Attend the gym regularly
Attend a yoga class
Run/walk 10k 
Reach my goal weight

I'll be updating this post as I cross items off of my list (and adding to it) and I hope to include a photograph or two on here to give you a little inspiration for your bucket list.

Do you have a bucket list? 
Have you thought about creating one? What are some of the things on it?

I would love to hear from you via the comments section below. 

*Happy Listing!*

<style>
  H6 {
    color: powderblue;
  }
</style>

posts.title: My Top 5 Europe Destinations
posts.markdown:
It is no secret that I love to travel and armed with my Nikon D3400 Camera to capture key moments of my adventures, I plan to visit 5 destinations throughout this year and 2019. 

I have set my sights on travelling Europe as I believe it is a fantastic treasure trove of incredible travel experiences.

Here are my top 5 planned destinations which might inspire you start planning your vacation list.

Have you got any trips planned for this year and if so, where?

![alt](/content/images/2018/03/Amsterdam.jpg)

*Barcelona, Spain 2019*


######4|

*Northern Lights, Iceland - 2019*

######5|

posts.title: Top 10 Inspirational Travel Quotes
posts.markdown:
Who doesn't love travel quotes? For me, they evoke inspiration to live life to the fullest and feed my inner wanderlust to explore and see the world for what it is really is, which is absolutely beautiful.

Here are my top 10 favourite travel quotes collected over time. Whether you're an avid traveler, or just seeking a sense of momentary escape from the daily grind of routine, these are perfect to fuel that wanderlust and inspire you to pack up everything and head out into the unknown.

######5|

######7|

posts.title: (Untitled)
posts.markdown:
Enriched with colourful tall brick buildings, open sky blue gorgeous skyline, easing our way into the relaxed and easy going attitude towards life and yes, I am talking about the wonderful and stunning city of Amsterdam. Over three days, we explored the city by foot (as we were staying quite central) soaking up the relaxed and vibrant culture that the city had to offer. 

Amsterdam has so much to offer that we couldn’t manage to do all of it in one trip but just enough to hopefully return again.  

This wonderful city deserves so much more than just the few days than travellers give it, however, if all you have is a couple of days, like me, you'll want to make the most of it, and here is a brief itinerary of what I would give to a first-time traveller visiting Amsterdam for the first time.

######Canal tour

Amsterdam is a city surround by water. The canals of Amsterdam are incredibly beautiful, and picturesque. there’s nothing like seeing the city from a boat. Skip the big canal boat tours you see around the city — they’re overpriced. You can often hire a private boat tour for about 20 Euros an hour (look for guides around the Red Light District). Moreover, you can also take the open-air Canal Hopper Small Boat. This is the company I use when I run group tours to the city — the boats are small, the tours more intimate, and your driver will give you a good personalized tour. The tours last about an hour.

The Rijksmuseum is located right next to the Van Gogh Museum, and after years of renovation, it’s now beautifully remodeled. The museum still features an extensive Rembrandt collection, and you’ll be able to see the famous painting “The Night Watch.” Besides Rembrandt, there’s also an incredible and robust collection of other classic Dutch painters, like Frans Hals and Johannes Vermeer. Over one million works of art, craftworks, and historical objects are kept in the collection, and around 8,000 objects are on display in the museum so be sure to budget a few hours!
FOAMThis photography museum houses wonderful pictures and sees few crowds despite being in the main part of the city. It’s a must for any photography lover. The exhibitions are constantly changing so you never know what you might see! They have a beautiful outdoor garden too. It’s a small museum and doesn’t take long to see.
I have mixed feelings about zoos.

I don't like seeing animals contained, but I don't like to see them die in the wild through human or natural causes either.

That said, I've been intrigued by Artis Zoo for quite some time,  not least because I have cycled and sailed around it on a number of occasions, seen the heads of giraffe pop up over a fence and started to wonder what lies within.

Last week, with my 18 month old nephew visiting, I found out!
In all honesty, I don’t like this place. I found it to be anticlimactic. You basically do a slow walk through the house as the crowds pack the place. You don’t get to let everything soak in as you’re being pushed from behind by the endless crowds. It’s maddening! But, if you don’t mind waiting in line and you’re curious about Anne (I think the Jewish History Museum does a more thorough job of relating the events in Anne Frank’s life to the Holocaust), it might be worth the visit for you. You can book tickets online up to two months in advance, which lets you skip the line. If you don’t do this, get there very early in the morning to avoid the long queue that develops over the course of the day!

I don't like seeing animals contained, but I don't like to see them die in the wild through human or natural causes either.

That said, I've been intrigued by Artis Zoo for quite some time, not least because I have cycled and sailed around it on a number of occasions, seen the heads of giraffe pop up over a fence and started to wonder what lies within.

Last week, with my 18 month old nephew visiting, I found out!
In all honesty, I don’t like this place. I found it to be anticlimactic. You basically do a slow walk through the house as the crowds pack the place. You don’t get to let everything soak in as you’re being pushed from behind by the endless crowds. It’s maddening! But, if you don’t mind waiting in line and you’re curious about Anne (I think the Jewish History Museum does a more thorough job of relating the events in Anne Frank’s life to the Holocaust), it might be worth the visit for you. You can book tickets online up to two months in advance, which lets you skip the line. If you don’t do this, get there very early in the morning to avoid the long queue that develops over the course of the day!
